Redux

Introduction

Redux is a JavaScript library to manage the state (or data) of your application, helping you to manage the data you display and how you respond to user actions. It's ideal for Single Page Applications (SPA).

Redux is no relation to React. You can use Redux with React, Angular, Ember, jQuery, or vanilla JavaScript.

A Google Chrome extension exists for Redux and can be installed from here

Install Redux

Redux can be installed using NPM (Node Package Manager). Open the terminal and enter the following command to install Redux as a dependency of your project. You will require a package.json file.

Should you want to use Redux with React, use NPM to install react-redux as a dependency also. The react-redux module makes the connection between React and Redux.

                        

$ npm install redux --save

# For React install react-redux also
$ npm install react-redux --save

Store

The store is a single object that contains the state of our whole application. The store cannot be directly modified. The only way to do so is through the use of reducers. Reducers are triggered using actions.

Within our React project you will find a src directory. Within this directory a file named index.js can be found. Now that react-redux has been installed using NPM (Node Package Manager), we can import it into the index.js file.

In the example below, the App component within the src/components directory contains our application.

If we want to link our React application with Redux store, we first have to let our application know that the store exists. The Provider is the first major part of the react-redux library, it is the root of your components. The Provider wrapped around our App component provides us access to the Store throughout our entire application. It is a React component given to us by the react-redux library. It has one purpose, to provide the store to it's child components.

                        

import React from 'react'
import ReactDOM from 'react-dom'
import { Provider } from 'react-redux'
import App from './components/App'

ReactDOM.render (
   <Provider>
      <App />
   </Provider>,
   document.getElementById('root')
)

We can use the createStore method provided by Redux to create the store. The Provider is given the store as a prop. This makes the Redux store available to the connect() calls. Normally, you cannot use connect() without wrapping a parent component in <Provider>

                        

import React from 'react'
import ReactDOM from 'react-dom'
import { createStore } from 'redux'
import { Provider } from 'react-redux'
import App from './components/App'

// This is the store we create with Redux's createStore method
const store = createStore(myApp, {})

// Provider is given the store as a prop
ReactDOM.render (
   <Provider store={store}>
      <App />
   </Provider>,
   document.getElementById('root')
)

Now that we have provided the Redux store to our application, we can now connect our React components to it. There is no way to directly interact with the store, but we can either retrieve data by obtaining it's current state, or change it's state by dispatching an action.

The react-redux library has connect. This is used to map the state of the store and dispatch to the props of a component.

An example of a simple example React component can be found below:

                        

import {connect} from 'react-redux'

const ToDoItem = ({todo, destroyTodo}) => {
   return (
      <div>
         {todo.text}
         <span onClick={destroyTodo}> x </span>
      </div>
   )
}

const mapStateToProps = state => {
   return {
      todo : state.todos[0]
   }
}

const mapDispatchToProps = dispatch => {
   return {
      destroyTodo : () => dispatch({
         type : 'DESTROY_TODO'
      })
   }
}

export default connect(
   mapStateToProps,
   mapDispatchToProps
)(TodoItem)

mapStateToProps and mapDispatchToProps are both pure functions that are provided the stores 'state' and 'dispatch' respectively. Furthermore, both functions have to return an object, whose keys will then be passed on as the props of the component they are connected to. In this case, mapStateToProps returns an object with only one key : 'todo', and mapDispatchToProps returns an object with the destroyTodo key. The connected component (which is exported) provides todo and destroyTodo as props to TodoItem.

Actions

Actions allow you to send data from your application to the store. They are plain JavaScript objects with a type property that indicates the type of action being performed.

                        

import { ADD_TODO, REMOVE_TODO } from '../actionTypes'

Action Creators

Action creators are the functions that create actions.

                        

function addTodo(text) {
   return {
      type: ADD_TODO,
      text
   }
}

Reducers

Actions describe how something has happened but don't specify how the application's state changes in response. This is the job of reducers.
